citeinfo.origin: Center for Geospatial Data Analysis (CGDA) (data compiler)
citeinfo.title: AQUIFERS_BEDROCK_USGS_IN: Bedrock Aquifer Systems in Indiana (United States Geological Survey, 1:500,000, Polygon Shapefile)
citeinfo.othercit: Data is compiled from: Fenelon, J.M., Bobay, K.E., Greeman, T.K., Hoover, M.E., Cohen, D.A., Fowler, K.K., Woodfield, M.C., Doss, P.K., and Durbin, J.M., 1994, Hydrogeologic Atlas of Aquifers in Indiana, U.S. Geological Survey Water-Resources Investigations Report 92-4142, 197 p. <http://in.water.usgs.gov/atlasweb/>

descript.abstract: Four types of bedrock aquifers in 12 water-management basins identified by the Indiana Natural Resources Commission (INRC) in Indiana were identified by the USGS in U.S. Geological Survey Water-Resources Investigations Report 92-4142 (Fenelon and others, 1994). The source scale of the maps depicting aquifers was 1:500,000. Aquifer maps are based on information from hydrogeologic sections and from previous studies. Attributes were compiled from tabular information contained in Fenelon and others (1994). Information contained in the report was used to identify mapped rock units within aquifer systems and distribute the aquifer characteristics to those polygons.
descript.purpose: These data are intended for use at a scale of 1:500,000 or smaller. Owing to the small scale and sparseness of data used for the aquifer-systems mapping, the primary intended use is for regional data display and analysis rather than specific local or site-specific data analysis.
descript.supplinf:
The following is excerpted from Fenelon and others (1994, page 1):
"Wells completed in the bedrock aquifers generally have lower yields than wells in most of the sand and gravel aquifers, but the bedrock aquifers are areally widespread and a major source of water for many domestic users and some large users of ground water. Carbonate rocks (limestone and dolostone); sandstones; complexly interbedded sandstone, siltstone, shale, limestone, and coal; and an upper weathered zone in low permeability rocks comprise the types of bedrock aquifers. Aquifers in carbonate rocks of Silurian, Devonian, and Mississippian age underlie about one-half of Indiana and are the most important of the bedrock aquifers in terms of yield and areal extent. The other principal type of bedrock aquifer is sandstone, which underlies large areas in the southwestern one-fifth of Indiana. The mapped sandstones are located within deposits of complexly interbedded sandstone, siltstone, shale, limestone, and coal of Mississippian and Pennsylvanian age. These complex deposits yield small quantities of water of variable quality, but they are important if they are the only available aquifer in a particular area. The remaining bedrock aquifer, which is used when it is the sole source of water for an area, is an upper weathered zone developed primarily in siltstone and shale of Mississippian and Devonian age and, to a lesser extent, in some of the shale and limestone of Ordovician age. No aquifer is mapped in the southeastern corner of Indiana, which is underlain by shale and limestone of Ordovician age."
A LYR (Aquifers_bedrock_USGS_IN.lyr) file accompanies this data layer to assist the user with symbolization so that the vertical sequence of aquifer systems can be visualized in geographic information system (GIS) software, particularly ESRI software products.

theme.themekey: complexly interbedded sandstone, shale, limestone, and coal aquifer

idinfo.native: ESRI ArcGIS shapefile format, Microsoft Windows XP, approximately 8.63 MB

attracc.attraccr: The attributes contained in this layer are those reported in Fenelon and others, 1994. The accuracy of these attributes is not known. The accuracy of the reported aquifer characteristics is not intended to represent site-specific conditions, but to identify types of aquifers and typical extents of rock units likely to contain and produce ground water. The thickness ranges and potential aquifer yield ranges are estimates of regional aquifer characteristics.

dataqual.logic: Checks for sliver polygons were conducted and resolved by attributing the slivers with the "Aquifer_Type" value of the adjacent polygon in the same "Basin" and dissolving the boundaries. No topological checks were conducted on this data set. The shapefile represents a vertical distribution of aquifers, and the polygon boundaries overlap. In places with overlapping aquifer system polygons, more than one potential aquifer exists.
dataqual.complete: Layer includes data of unconsolidated aquifers including aquifer type, local names, thickness, and potential aquifer yield as presented in the USGS publication Hydrogeologic Atlas of Aquifers of Indiana (Fenelon and others, 1994). Where a type of aquifer was less than 15 square miles in areal extent, it was not mapped because of scale limitations.

horizpa.horizpar: The source publication (Fenelon, 1994) reports no information on horizontal accuracy of the original 1:500,000-scale mapping. Horizontal accuracy is largely contingent upon accuracy of the source publication. ESRI ArcGIS was used to georeference vector data using Indiana county boundaries.

vertacc.vertaccr: Vertical accuracy was not a factor in the digital production of the data set.

citeinfo.title: Fenelon, J.M., Bobay, K.E., Greeman, T.K., Hoover, M.E., Cohen, D.A., Fowler, K.K., Woodfield, M.C., Doss, P.K., and Durbin, J.M., 1994, Hydrogeologic atlas of aquifers in Indiana: U.S. Geological Survey Water-Resources Investigations Report 92-4142, 197 p.
citeinfo.othercit:
Tabular data in Fenelon and others (1994) provided the content of the attribute table built for this data layer. The tables used for the aquifers in each water management basin are as follows:
Lake Michigan River Basin aquifers: Table 3, page 23
St Joseph River Basin aquifers: Table 4, page 33
Kankakee River Basin aquifers: Table 5, page 47
Maumee River Basin aquifers: Table 6, page 61
Upper Wabash River Basin aquifers: Table 7, page 81
Middle Wabash River Basin aquifers: Table 8, page 99
Lower Wabash River Basin aquifers: Table 9, page 110
White River Basin aquifers: Table 10, page 132
East Fork White River Basin aquifers: Table 11, page 153
Whitewater River Basin aquifers: Table 12, page 164
Patoka River Basin aquifers: Table 13, page 174
Ohio River Basin aquifers: Table 14, page 196

srcinfo.srccitea: USGS Hydrogeologic Atlas for Indiana; Fenelon and others, 1994
srcinfo.srccontr: Mapped aquifer polygons and tabular data for building the attribute table.

citeinfo.title: WATERSHEDS_HUC14_SUBWATERSHEDS_USGS_IN: Subwatersheds, 14-digit, Hydrologic Units, in Indiana, (United States Geological Survey, 1:24000 Polygon Shapefile)
LANDSURVEY_COUNTY_POLY_IN: County Boundaries of Indiana (Indiana Geological Survey, 1:24,000, Polygon Shapefile)

srcinfo.srccontr: Base data for georeferencing original aquifer systems boundaries from Fenelon and others (1994)

citeinfo.title: BEDROCK_GEOL_MM48_IN: Bedrock Geology of Indiana (Indiana Geological Survey, 1:500,000, Polygon Shapefile)
citeinfo.othercit:
IGS Inventory Bar Code Number 11000040
This shapefile was derived and modified from a preexisting published paper map: Gray, H.H., Ault, C.H., and Keller, S.J., 1987, Bedrock geologic map of Indiana, Indiana Geological Survey Miscellaneous Map 48, scale 1:500,000.

procstep.procdesc: USGS personnel provided IGS personnel with EPS (image) files of the extents of bedrock aquifer systems for each water management basin in Indiana, as presented in the Hydrogeologic Atlas of Aquifers in Indiana publication (Fenelon and others, 1994). IGS personnel exported the data from Adobe Illustrator as PNG files at 900 dpi with a transparent background. The PNG files were geoferenced in ESRI ArcMap to LANDSURVEY_COUNTY_POLY_IN.shp and the mapped aquifer boundaries were digitized using the "Trace" function of the ArcMap Editor Toolbar. Any water management basin boundaries retained during the georeferencing and digitization of the aquifer system boundaries were dissolved using the "Aquifer_Type" attribute to create continuous statewide aquifer system layers.
procstep.srcused: Figures from USGS Hydrogeologic Atlas for Indiana
procstep.srcprod: cba_state.shp (carbonate bedrock aquifers), sa_state.shp (sandstone aquifers), cisslca_state.shp (complexly interbedded sandstone, shale, limestone, and coal aquifers), uwba_state.shp (upper weathered bedrock aquifers).

cntperp.cntorg: Indiana Geological Survey, Center for Geospatial Data Analysis

procstep.procdesc: The Indiana Natural Resources Commission (INRC) water management basin boundaries were replicated using 1:24000-scale HUC14 subwatershed boundaries. This step was conducted for two reasons: (1) the 1:500,000-scale source maps with the original river basin boundaries were not coincident with other mapped HUC6 (major river basin hydrologic units) boundaries for Indiana, and (2) the quality of the basin boundaries after tracing from the EPS/PNG image files was poor.

cntperp.cntorg: Indiana Geological Survey, Center for Geospatial Data Analysis

procstep.procdesc: Each aquifer system was combined using the "Union" tool in ESRI ArcMap with the reconstructed INRC basin boundaries to discretize the aquifer systems in preparation for joining with an attribute table of aquifer characteristics compiled from Fenelon and others (1994).
procstep.srcprod: cba_basins.shp (carbonate bedrock aquifers), sa_basins.shp (sandstone aquifers), cisslca_basins.shp (complexly interbedded sandstone, shale, limestone, and coal aquifers), uwba_basins.shp (upper weathered bedrock aquifers).

cntperp.cntorg: Indiana Geological Survey, Center for Geospatial Data Analysis

procstep.procdesc: Each aquifer system data layer was was combined with the state bedrock geology data layer using the "Union" tool in ESRI ArcMap to merge aquifer system boundaries with bedrock geology polygons and attributes (especially the "ROCK_UNIT" field). Many local or common names identified as bedrock aquifers in Fenelon and others (1994) are mapped rock units in BEDROCK_GEOL_MM48_IN.shp. The bedrock geology for each basin with more than one mapped bedrock aquifer system was exported for further processing.
procstep.srcprod: efw_bedrock_geo.shp, lwbash_bedrock_geo.shp, mwbash_bedrock_geo.shp, uwbash_bedrock_geo.shp, white_bedrock_geo.shp, ohio_bedrock_geo.shp, patoka_bedrock_geo.shp

cntperp.cntorg: Indiana Geological Survey, Center for Geospatial Data Analysis

procstep.procdesc: An attribute table of aquifer types and characteristics was compiled from tabular information in Fenelon and others, 1994. A unique ID was assigned to each combination of basin, aquifer system, and local name (if the aquifer system and local name were associated by unique aquifer characteristics such as thickness and/or aquifer yield).

cntperp.cntorg: Indiana Geological Survey, Center for Geospatial Data Analysis

procstep.procdesc: Aquifers with detailed bedrock unit information referenced in the tabular data compiled from Fenelon and others (1994) were identified and combined using the "Union" tool in ESRI ArcMap to merge the detailed bedrock geology information with the mapped extents of the bedrock aquifer systems. The unique ID assigned to each basin and aquifer system was added to the output shapefiles to serve as a "join field" to append the compiled aquifer data to the spatial data. Detailed information was available in the Lower Wabash River Basin for the complexly interbedded sandstone, shale, limestone, and coal aquifer system; in the Patoka River Basin for the sandstone aquifer system, and in the East Fork White, Middle Wabash, Ohio, Patoka, White, and Upper Wabash River Basins for the carbonate bedrock aquifer system. The Lake Michigan Basin, St. Joseph, Maumee, Whitewater, and Kankakee River Basins had only one bedrock aquifer identified and mapped for each basin.
procstep.srcused: aquifer_table.xls, efw_bedrock_geo.shp, lwbash_bedrock_geo.shp, mwbash_bedrock_geo.shp, uwbash_bedrock_geo.shp, white_bedrock_geo.shp, ohio_bedrock_geo.shp, patoka_bedrock_geo.shp, cba_basins.shp, sa_basins.shp, cisslca_basins.shp, uwba_basins.shp
procstep.srcprod: cisslca_geo_lwbash.shp, sa_geo_patoka.shp, cba_geo_efw.shp, cba_geo_mwbash.shp, cba_geo_ohio.shp, cba_geo_patoka.shp, cba_geo_white.shp, cba_geo_uwbash.shp

cntperp.cntorg: Indiana Geological Survey, Center for Geospatial Data Analysis

procstep.procdesc: In areas where bedrock aquifers were mapped but the mapped extent of the identified ROCK_UNIT did not fully cover the aquifer system in a particular basin, the following approach was used to distribute the aquifer attributes to the remainder of the aquifer system polygons: the ROCK_UNIT of the nonaquifer polygon was identified, and the closest underlying aquifer was assigned to the polygon, along with the unique ID assigned to that aquifer. The stratigraphic column for Paleozoic rocks in Indiana was used to identify the relationships of the aquifers and the overlying units. The thickness of the overlying unit was taken into consideration to assess the plausibility of accessing the underlying aquifer by drilling through the overlying aquitard. The individual aquifer system polygons per basin were dissolved in ArcMap using the ID field. Unique ID values were also assigned to the aquifer system/basin combinations without detailed ROCK_UNIT polygons. The basins with detailed geologic/aquifer information were merged together with the aquifer system layers.
procstep.srcused: cisslca_geo_lwbash.shp, sa_geo_patoka.shp, cba_geo_efw.shp, cba_geo_mwbash.shp, cba_geo_ohio.shp, cba_geo_patoka.shp, cba_geo_white.shp, cba_geo_uwbash.shp, cba_basins.shp, sa_basins.shp, cisslca_basins.shp, uwba_basins.shp.

cntperp.cntorg: Indiana Geological Survey, Center for Geospatial Data Analysis

procstep.procdesc: The attribute tables of the output files were checked for uniformity, and all aquifer systems were merged into a single shapefile in ArcMap to create a statewide bedrock aquifer system data layer.

cntperp.cntorg: Indiana Geological Survey, Center for Geospatial Data Analysis

procstep.procdesc: This metadata file was pre-parsed and parsed using CNS (Chew and Spit, v. 2.6.1) and MP (Metadata Parser, v. 2.7.1) software written by Peter N. Schweitzer (U.S. Geological Survey). The errors generated by MP were all addressed and corrected, except that no values were assigned to "Abscissa_Resolution" and "Ordinate_Resolution."

cntperp.cntorg: Indiana Geological Survey, Center for Geospatial Data Analysis

edom.edomv: Complexly interbedded sandstone, shale, limestone, and coal aquifer
edom.edomvd: Complexly interbedded sandstone, shale, limestone, and coal aquifer

attr.attrdef: Unique identification number assigned to river basin and aquifer systems in Indiana

edom.edomvd: East Fork White River water management basin
Lake Michigan (in Indiana) water management basin
Lower Wabash River water management basin
Middle Wabash River water management basin
Ohio River (in Indiana) water management basin
St. Joseph River water management basin
Upper Wabash River water management basin

attr.attrdef: Local aquifer names and types. Many aquifers have multiple local names cited by various authors. The literature sources for each local name are listed in the field named "Name_cite."
Literature sources for local aquifer names cited in Fenelon and others, 1994. Various sources correspond to various names given in the field named "Local_name."

Estimated aquifer thickness range (in feet) for aquifer system. Various thickness ranges correspond to various aquifer units given in the field "Local_name" and various literature sources given in the field named "Thk_cite."
Literature sources for aquifer thickness ranges cited in Fenelon and others, 1994. Various sources correspond to various thickness ranges given in the field named "Thk_ft."

Potential aquifer yield range (gallons per minute) estimated for aquifer system. Various yield ranges correspond to various aquifer units given in the field "Local_name" and various literature sources given in the field named "Yield_cite."
Maximum potential aquifer yield estimated for aquifer system

rdom.attrmres: 1 gallon per minute, but usually rounded to 10 gpm

attr.attrdef: Literature sources for aquifer yield cited in Fenelon and others, 1994. Various sources correspond to various yield ranges given in the field named "Yield_gpm."

metainfo.metuc: This metadata file is intended to accompany the data set identified and received from the IGS. It is not to be altered or summarized. IGS does not support secondary distribution. If this data set was received from anyone besides the IGS, this metadata file and the data set it describes may lack integrity.
